description.narrative: The UN Women programme includes promotion of women's leadership in peace and security, increased political participation, strengthening womens' economic empowerment and to reduce gender-based violence against women and girls. Sweden will also support UN Women in establishing in Somalia.

UN Womens program inkluderar bl a att främja kvinnors ledarskap i fred och säkerhet, öka kvinnors politiska deltagande, stärka kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt samt minska könsbaserat våld mot kvinnor och flickor. Sverige kommer även att stödja UN Women i att etablera sig i Somalia.

participating-org.narrative: UNWOMEN/United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women
UNWOMEN/United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women

sector.narrative: Women’s rights organisations and movements, and government institutions

tag.narrative: 5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: In 2015, UN Women Somalia restructured its 2014-2016 Strategic Note (SN) to respond to emerging priorities of the Somali government. The previous 2014-2016 SN, which preceded the Somali New Deal Compact, did not fully reflect federal and state level priorities and was not fully aligned with modalities for delivering aid to Somalia. In consultation with the Embassy of Sweden in Nairobi, the Office conducted a mid-term review of its Somalia Country Programme and restructured the 2014-2016 SN to provide clarity of UN Women’s added value in Somalia, to tackle slow delivery and to address the many operational challenges on the ground. The revision of the SN was geared towards aligning the work of UN Women with the relevant peace and state building goals, and with the aid architecture defined in the Compact document.As a result of the review, UN Women changed its strategic direction, reduced its presence in Garowe and Hargeisa, and moved its centre of gravity to Mogadishu. Three priority areas were identified by UN Women as key:• The strengthening of UN Women’s engagement by focusing on fewer thematic areas, more specifically on Women’s Political Empowerment and Leadership; Access to Justice and Security; and some initial focus on Prevention and Access to Essential Services to End Violence Against Women and Girls.• Focusing on analytical work and better use of gender statistics through data gathering and analysis to inform effective programming. • A more strategic approach to mainstream gender across the United Nations Country Team (UNCT) and in development documents and frameworks guiding the work of development partners in Somalia. One major oucome of UN Womens work was an increase in women representation in both houses of the Federal Parliament after the 2016 federal parliamentary elections was achieved as a result of strong advocacy, lobbying and awareness raising by UN Women together with other UN partners and wider international community. UN Women has with support from Sweden facilitated the establishment of a coordination platform for women, peace and security, which brings together women parliamentarians, civil society, Federal line Ministries, State Gender Ministries, and those from the private sector. The platform aims at consolidating joint advocacy efforts and facilitating women’s effective participation in ongoing political processes and peacebuilding efforts. It is still too early to see any results from this work. UN Women also played an active part in the development of the UN Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment Policy. The status of the policy and Un Women’s role in the implementation is however still unclear. In the aid architecture linked to the implementation of Somalia’s National Development Plan a specific Pillar on gender and HR has been established. UN Women together with UNSOM HR are the UN lead in the Pillar group that is co-chaired by Sweden and the Ministry for Women and Human Rights Development. UN Women has provided support to the Ministry for the development of the terms of reference of the Pillar Working Group and the development of a monitoring and evaluation framework. It is still too early to see any results from this work.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
